qas.question: How much money did the Football League receive in revenues from television money for a two year agreement in 1986?

answers.text: the Football League received £6.3 million for a two-year agreement in 1986

qas.question: In 1998, the deal was renewed for what amount over four years?

answers.text: deal was renewed in 1988, the price rose to £44 million over four years.

qas.question: In 1988, how many clubs threateded to leave and form another league?

answers.text: ten clubs threatened to leave and form a "super league"

qas.question: Why did some of the top teams consider leaving the Football league?

answers.text: to capitalise on the growing influx of money being pumped into the sport.

context: <b11_0>Television money<b11_0/> had also become much more important; <a0_0>the Football League received <a6_0><b12_0>£6.3 million<b12_0/><a6_0/> for a <a7_0>two<a7_0/>-year agreement in 1986<a0_0/>, but when that <a1_0>deal was renewed in 1988, the price rose to <a4_0><b9_0><b13_0>£44 million<b13_0/><a4_0/> over <a8_0>four<a8_0/> years.<b9_0/><a1_0/> The <a5_0>1988<a5_0/> negotiations were the first signs of a breakaway league; <a2_0>ten clubs threatened to leave and form a "<b10_0>super league<b10_0/>"<a2_0/>, but were eventually persuaded to stay. As stadiums improved and match attendance and revenues rose, the country's top teams again considered leaving the Football League in order <a3_0>to capitalise on the growing influx of money being pumped into the sport.
